div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains is $9 to Brindisi. The combined Sea and speical train fare has been reduced to $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: RUSSIAN DIPLOMACY
div.p: The diplomatic skill of the Russian Govern¬ment in devising and pushing its plans is, we suspect, a little overrated in Western Europe. It is there believed that St. Peters¬burg is served by hundreds of able and uns¬crupulous agen s, who all pull together, and all carry out far reaching plans, which they do not talk about, but thoroughly understand. The Russian Government is, therefore, it is alleged, successful beyond all other Govern¬ments, so successful that any whisper of its future plans of aggrandisement, even when badly authenticated, sometimes causes a flutter among the nations. Russia, it is said, never, even if defeated, gives up her purpo¬ses ; and as she has no Parliament to distract her, and no diplomatists can contend with her agents in aubtlety and foresight, sba almost always succeeds in them. The result is a widely diffused alarm, and a consequent exaltation of the Russian repute for ability, which of itself increases the weight of Russia in the councils of the world. The facts, however, if carefully observed, do not bear out these pessimistic opinions. Russia, it is true, has spread far and fast in Northern Asia, where there was nothing strong enough to resist her, and where, it must in justice be added, her administration, though always too daa- potio, and occasionally violent and cruel, is distinctly better through long terms of years than the administrations it superseded. Bnt she has not succeeded at all strikingly in making herself a "world-Power.” She She has feared to colonise any place divided from herself by the sea. She has not, after a century of effort, broken her way to open water yet. She has not conquered Constantinople, and her land road to it is as solidly barred as ever. Bhe has, by permitting the conversion of Germany from a loosely knit Federation into a strongly knit military Empire, immeasurably reduced her own influence in Europe ; has, indeed, compelled hmelf to lean for safety on an ally whose thoughts are not her thought®, and whose objects ere aaaeawily Inn in Aab ab hm oonpQad India to strengthen herself so greatly that an invasion from the North is most difficult; and goaded Japan into fighting her before she herself was nearly ready to repel and punish the assault. She has driven England, which at heart dis- likes fettering alliances, into a close alliance with the most formidable enemy of Russia on he Pacific ; has at the same time, by a series of amazing blunders, alienated the strong sym¬pathy formerly felt for her. in the United States ; and has forced the strongest and most united of clans, the world-wide Jewish people, with its controlling influence over finance and journalism, to become her irreconcilable foe. These can hardly be called successes, even if we refrain from comparing Russian diplo- matists and statesmen with Bismarck and Cavour, each of whom won for his master each splendid triumphs ; and the successive occu¬pants of the Russian Foreign Office have failed at another point which may prove hereafter of ever greater importance. They have failed in securing the confidence of the world, or even of that section of it whose ideas march fairly well with their own. We do not our¬selves believe, as most of our countrymen do, that this loss is a deserved, We see no reason for believing that falsity is imbedded in the Russian character, or that her diplomat¬ists despise a rigid adherence to truth more than the majority of their profession. Russia keeps European treaties fairly well, and has once or twice exhibited in difficult circumstance a fidelity to pecuniary engagements at once praiseworthy in itself and profitable to her credit We should have said that the innate Russian fault was a violent aggreesive- ness of demeanour rather than a silken falsity like that of the Byzantines. Bat it is mere matter of fact that her agents have in one way or another created a nearly universal distrust in her sincerity, and that this distrust hampers and burdens her at every turn. It was really disbelief in Russian promises which induced Japan to stake her existence as an independent Power upon the ohanoea of a long, exhausting, and most com plicated war. But for distrust as to the security of the “open door,” Russia might have almost a free hand in settling the destiny of China. But for a suspicion which, jnst or unjust, seems irremovable, Great Britain and Russia would long ago have come to an agree¬ment about influence in Asia which would, to say the least of it, have reduced their financial hardens in that continent by one-half. It is Russia's indefiniteness as to pledgee, to use the most polite expression, which prevents the world from securing for her the o]ear water¬way to the Mediterranean which she very naturally thinks her right Let Russia but convince the world that she intends to go straight, and her career, even if it is still a career of conquest, will be smoothed for her in every direction. Nobody wants to keep her away from the water out of pare spite ; bat then nobody believes what her agents, who are struggling to clear the road to the water for her, say or promise. To what, then, are we to ascribe the ten¬dency of successive Russian Governments to inspire a distrust which, so far from streng-thening, cripples them I They must know that it is an obstacle, and why do they allow it to grow np ! In part, no donbt, it is due to the fact that under an obscurantist autocracy it is the unscrupulous who most frequently rise to the top ; but it is also in part due to a very curious failure within the autocracy itself. Every one in Western Europe thinks of the Russian agents as slaves to a central Com¬mittee ; but in reality the Russian Govern¬ment gives its agents more of a free hand than is enjoyed by those of any other European Power. It leaves to its Ambassadors and Vice- a liberty as complete as it claims for it¬self, refuses to fetter them with detailed “instructions,” and requires of them nothing but success. Sometimes, when the agents are able and dreamstanoes are favourable, that policy succeeds; and sometimes, when, as often happens, they are stupid cr obstinate men, it fails; but always it leaves to oompa* ratively irresponsible men too much power, and always it tempts them to make promises and sign arrangements which the ultimate authority is obliged more or less decisively to repudiate. The agents are, of course, eager for approval at home, and they are also eager to be, and to appear to be, great personages at their stations. They straggle for sucess, they grow jealous of each other, they try to make everything pleasant to St. Petersburg, till their Government, there is reason to believe, often grows bewildered by the information oonveyed, and a sort of contest springs up between the delegating authority and the authorities who are delegated. There is an incoherence in their action which at once suggests to the observe* —who, be it remembered, is full of distrust— that somebody is cheating, or hiding truths, or making promises which it is not inten ded to keep. It is dear, for example even from the very imperfect revelations that have reached the general ear, that a struggle of thia kind occurred between St Petersburg and the Viceroy of the Far East; that the Tsar in tended a compromise while his Viceroy tend¬ed either to secure a grand diplomatic victory or to force a war, the result being that the Japanese thought that they were being amused while preparations went on,'and at last refused to be delayed any longer. Could they have trusted their antagonists, they might have assented to an arrangement which would at least have postponed war for five years ; but with Admiral Alexeieff saying one thing and the Foreign Office another, they at last came to disbelieve both, aud stuck for their own interests exclusively. England regarded the whole affair as proof positive at once of Russian aggressiveness and Russian duplicity bat the loose system through which the autocracy works is at least as much to blame as any inherent duplicity in the Russian character, os any quality of excessiveness in Russian ambition.

div.head: THE , EGYPTIAN , GAZETTE, MONDAY,,,.SEPTEMBER. 41, 4905
TIIE CAUCASIAN REVOLT,
£20,000,000 DAMAGES-
BRITISH SUBJECTS SAFE,
div.p: ST. PETEBSBUBQ, September 9. The latest telegrams from the Caucasus are vague and confused. It is impossible to say whether the rising is spreading or subsiding. Against the reassuring official telegrams, there are private messages recounting wholesale massacres of Armenians. It is feared that the four British subjects at Balakhany have been shot or perished in the flames. (fiswtw) BAKU, September 9. The Armenian Bishop at Shusha telegraphs an appalling account of the devastation there. The town is a mass of rains. The fighting between the Tartars and the Armenians lasted five days. Hundreds of killed and wounded are lying in the streets. He appeals for aid for the starving people who number thousands. It is estimated that the actual destruction to the oil industry at Baku involves a direct loss of £20,000,000, while it will require several millions to restore the workings. In addition there will be immense losses to the Russian industries using naphtha as a fuel. (BsalsrJ ST. PETEBSBUBO, September 9. It is annonnoed from Baku that the damages caused by the fires are estimated at 500,000,000 francs, and that in the fights between the Tartars and Armenians 1,500 people have been killed. (Ham) BAKU, September 10. The Vice-Consul telegraphs that all the British subjects are safe. (Reuter)

div.head: THE) EARTHQUAKE IN ITALY.
2,500 KILLED.
THOUSANDS HOMELESS.
ROME, September 9.
div.p: The Government is taking special measures to relieve the terrible distress caused by the earthquake The soldiers have laboured unceasingly in the work or rescue- Thousands are homeless. The mortality is still undetermined. (Reuter)

CATANZABO, September 10. The latest reports regarding the earthquake show that 300 persons were killed at Fargheli, 200 at Japplo and 2000 killed and injured at Martirano. Fresh shocks took place at Reggio di Calabria yesterday afternoon. The population was panic stricken. (B.) ROME, September 10. The Kaiser and M. Lonbet have telegraphed their condolences to the King on the disasters in Calabria. (Bam)

div.head: MARQUESS OF LONDONDERRY'S SPEECH.
. THE ANGLO-JAPANESE TREATY.
div.p: LONDON, September 10. The Marquess of Londonderry, speaking at Stockton, extolled the Japanese magnanimity in the peace settlement, and declared that the Anglo-Japanese treaty was of great benefit to the whole world.

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY.
NEGOTIATIONS BEGUN.
div.p: PARIS, September 9. M. Rosen has commenced negotiations with M. Rouvier regarding Moroccoo. (Reuter.)

div.head: EXPLOSION AT UNIONSTOWN.
THE TOKIO RIOT.
TOWN SETTLING DOWN.
BARON KATSURA'S STATEMENTS.
div.p: TOKIO, September 9. At an informal meeting of the members of the Parliament, Baron Katsnra made a reas¬suring statement showing that Japan has not agreed not to fortify the La Perouse Straits, but only guaranteed a free passage. He also stated that Japan, acquires a free hand in Korea. The Minister of Marine emphasized the fact that the capture of Vladivostok would have demanded greater sacrifices than those at Port Arthur. These statements have tended to quieten the people. (Rssiisr) TOKIO, September 10. The town is settling down in consequence of reassuring official statements. No farther dis¬orders are feared. The Guards at the Foreign Legations have been withdrawn. It is believed that the Government will resign when the Diet meets. (Reuter)

div.head: THE POBIEDONOSET’S MUTINEERS.
! SEVENTY-FIVE SENTENCED.
div.p: ST. PETEBSBURG, September 9. The Court martial on the mutineers of the Pobiedonoset’s crew condemned 3 of them to death, 19 to penal servitude, and 33 to disci¬plinary work. Twenty were acquitted. (Reuter) ODESSA, September 9. Seventy five of the Pobiedonosets mutineers have been sentenced, three of them to death. (Sosos;

div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, September 10. The armistice in Manchuria has come into force. (Ham)

139 CASES, 46 DEATHS.

div.head: EGYPT AND ITALY.
div.p: The Royal Commission which has recently been enquiring into the condition of the Italian mercantile marine has made the following suggestions to the Italian Government which relate to sea communication between Egypt and Italy. (1) To create a direct fast weekly service, Genoa—Naples — Alexandria, carried on by 19 knot boats of 7,000 metric tons displacement. (2) A direct fast weekly service between Venice—Brindisi—Alexandria, carried on by large 19 knot steamers. (8) A fortnightly service from Genoa to Leghorn, Naples, Messina, Tunis, Tripoli, Alexandria, the Syrian porta, and Venice, and vice versa. This service would be weekly at Alexandria, one boat arriving every week from Venice and one from Genoa.

div.head: LOCAL AND'GENERAL
div.p: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the iZeitonn district of Cairo daring to-morrow and at dawn of the 13th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

KILLED BY A CART.—A native boy, ten years of age, named Mahmoud Ali El Gamal, was inn over by a cart at Karmons yesterday, and received severe internal injuries from which he shortly expired. The driver of the cart was arrested.

SAD DROWNING FATALITY. — We greatly regret to announce that whilst Sheikh Moha¬med Haronn, Grand Cadi of the Sudan, and his family were returning to Haifa from Assouan by steamer, his little daughter fell overboard and was drowned. The body of the ohild has not been recovered.

SUEZ CANAL,—Nine ships passed through the canal on Friday, paying in dues frs. 287,140.96. Of these five were English, one German, one French, one Italian, and 1 Austri¬an. The receipts from 89 ships which have passed through between the 1st, and 8th September amount to frs. 2,846,293.94.

SALT AND SODA COMPANY.—The monthly returns of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Co. Ltd. show that the sales daring last month amounted to L.E. 17,669.253 as against L.K 16,988,779 daring August 1904. Since the 1st January the total sales amount to L.E. 170,944.617 as against L.E. 169,210.380 during the corresponding last year.

THB CHOLERA IN FRANCE. —The President of the Quarantine Board has received a com¬munication from the French Sanitary delegate informing him that there is no cholera at Brest. Two suspected cases occured in that town and in a neighbouring locality but on being subjected to bacteriological examination no reaction was given.

THE EGYPTIAN ARMY.—El Bimbashi F. C. Heneker, Sndan Government has resigned his commission on the strength of the Egyptian Army. El Bimbashi H. W. Channer, 3rd Battalion, has been transferred to the Sudan Govern v enf. El Bimbashi Hon. W. A. Trefnsis, Aide-de-Camp to H. E. the Sirdar, has been transferred to the 8rd Battalion, and the former appointment will in future be held by El Bimbashi R. J. Collins, 15th Sudanese. El Bimbashi W. B. C Bridge, 11th Sudanese has been transferred to the 9th Sudanese.

BUBONIC PLAGUE.—Nine cases of plague were notified during the week ending last Saturday, of which one occured at Port Said and the remaining eight at Alexandria. The Port Said case ended fatally and there were also three deaths at Alexandria. No cure is reported for the whole week. Twelve cases were remaining under treatment at the end of the week, of which ten were at Alexandria, one at Damietta, and one at Assouan. Since the 1st January there have been 255 cases as against 795 during the corresponding period last year. Sunday’s bulletin reports two reco-veries at Alexandria.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We are informed that the Earl of Cromer is leaving Marseilles by the P. and 0, steamer Moldavia due at Port Said on the 18th October.
Mr. H. Boyle, Oriental Secretary at the British Agency, has arrived in Cairo.
Dr. Grumprecht; German Consul at Cairo, left for Europe on Saturday. Herr von Veraen, German Consul at Salonica, arrived on Thors day at Cairo and will replace Dr. Grumprecht daring his absence.

We are authorised to contradict the rumour spread lately by several of the Cairo vernacular papers that Lewa Lord Cecil Pasha, D.S.O., is to replace Sir R. Wingate as Sirdar, the latter retaining only the functions of Governor General of the Sudan.
Judge Harold A. Perry is leaving Marseilles on the 22nd inst by the Bibby liner Yorkshire.
lady Mollwraith is taking passage by the P. and O.'Moldavia, leaving London on the 6th October.
Mr. and Mrs. Lang Anderson and the Misses Anderson are likewise returning by the P. and 0. S.S. Moldavia.
We regret to announce the sudden death of Mr. S. Felice, which occured at Vienna on the 2nd inst, while the deceased was returning to Egypt from Marienbad.
Idris Bey Ragheb arrived at Alexandria yesterday by the Florio-Rubbattino mail boat
Mr. William Kay Marr has been provision ally appointed to the 3rd Circle of Irrigation as engineer on a monthly salary of £80.
Bimbashi R. J. Collins of the 15th Sudance, has been appelated A.D.C. to HR the-Birdee.
The General Manager reports that the em bankment and approach for the junction of the Nile Khargeh line with the Egyptian State Railway is now completed.

div.head: SIR WILLIAM GARSTIN ON UPPER ’NILE PROBLEMS.
div.p: Sir William Garstin in his: article entitled “Some problems of the Upper Nile" which has recently appeared ; in the September Nineteenth Century, and After,’’ after a most interesting description of the part played by the different rivers which together form the Nile, and a picturesque account of their prin¬cipal features, points out that by 1908, two and a half million seres of land in Egypt will require to be provided with perennial irriga¬tion. (Te most thin need five million of cobio metres of water must be stored. The Assouan dam will, perhaps, not be raised, and the Wadi Rayan will probably be left till »such time are the question of reclaim¬ing and irrigating the shallowlakes of, the Northern Delta shall,become one- of urgency,Farther storage of water, even if, the Assouan dam were raised, (would injure winter, navign tion on the Nila between Assouan and Cairo in. a year of low supply and would only furnish a partial solution of the problem. The extra water required can only be obtained by in- creasing the flow of,the Upper Nile during winter, spring, and early summer. Sir William Garstin then describes the scheme suggested by Mr. J. E. Beresford, late Impastor General of legation in India for the construction of a new Channel between Bor and the Sohat junction. The scheme would oertainly enable the whole summer discharge of the white Nile to reach Tewfi kieh with the minimum of loss, the marshes being used to receive the flood overflow. This new channel would be 322 miles in' length, while if the Bahr el Zeraf were cleared and freed of obstructions the distance from Bor to Tewfikieh would still be 498 miles,, and if the Bahr el Gebel was used it would be fifty-two miles longer. As regards distance the advantages of the Beresford's scheme are great, but the author points out that there are two difficulties; its possibly prohibitive cost owing to diffi¬cult levels which surveys may yet discover, and the practical difficulties in the way of actually constructing the channel. At the same time a regulator should be constructed near the outlet of the Albert Lake, as Sir William Willoooks has long urged, to secure permanency of supply in the river. Its cons¬truction is in Sir William Garstin's opinion ' the key to the whole question of the impro¬vement of the Upper Nile." Taming to the Bine Nile, the question of a Tsana reservoir cannot be discussed owing to the immense political difficulties connected therewith, and it is a little doubtful whether a suitable site for a Blue Nile reservoir exists in Anglo Egyptian territory. Perennial irriga¬tion in the Sudan south of Khartoum must for the present be abandoned, and all future schemes must almost certainly be devoted to the study of the improvement of winter and flood irrigation. Weirs will have to be constructed between Khartoum and Roeaires, and would be accompanied .by. a system of basins and distributory canals, Such basins might reduce the risk of flood in the Northern Nile valley in “high Nile” years. MISSIONARIES FOR THE SUDAN. THE CRONIES FAILURE.

div.head: ‘THE EFFECT ON THE D'EGYPTE.
div.p: The Church Missionary Society have com¬pleted plans for inaugurating a mission in the Sudan, and with that object in view are despatching on Ootober 19 three missionaries, a doctor, and two specially qualified industrial instructors. They are the Rev. F.B. Hadow, M.A., the Rev. A.Shaw, M.A., and the Rev. A.M. Thom, M.A, Mr. E. Lloyd, and Messrs. J. Comley, and R.C J.8. Wilmot. The society, it is understood, have recieved a cerdial joint invitation from Lord Cromer and the Sudan Government.

div.head: THE CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT, LIMITED.
div.p: The General Manager reports that the embankment and approach for the junction of the Nile Khargeh line with the Egyptain State Railroad is now completed.

div.head: THIRTY-FIVE PEOPLE BURIED.
WASHINGTON, September 10.
div.p: A tremendous explosion destroyed the powder works at Unionstown (Pennsylvania). 35 persons were buried in the ruins. (Reuter) BARON KAMURA ILL PORTSMOUTH (N.H.), September 10. Baron Kamura has been suddenly taken ill with intestinal trouble.

div.head: THE RECAPTURE OF SANA.
div.p: The latest reports from the Yemen show that the success of Ahmed Pari Pasha was due to the astonishing courage with which his troops repeatedly rushed formidably en- trenched positions with the bayonet in the face of a very heavy fire. The actions at Suk el Khamis, Mufhak, and Kamlan were all decided by these offensive tactics, though the veteran Marshal was denied the farther reinforcement of 25,000 men which he demanded, and might well have feared to risk heavy losses. The total Turkish force in the province is now estimated et 45,000 man.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moes liner Tabor arrived yesterday from Liverpool, via Gibraltar and with mafia, and general Paris, September 5th. No sooner was M. Cronies buried than those interested in the Say concern and in the Sucreries d' Egypte went to work to examine the situation, and to see what1 remedies' could be found to save the existence, at least, of the former venture. Apparently all efforts will be concentrated to that end, so that the concentration of the production in which thousands of people are engaged ought not to be stopped one moment. M. Peytel (the managing director of the Credit Algerian)' has meanwhile been entrusted with the duties' of'Chairman of the Sav Company and M. Pelissier with those of technical director of the factories. It is not likely that M. Peytel, who in- recent years has been one of the busiest' of bank directors, would definitely, sesame the sucession of M. Oronier. As to the Sucreries of Egypte, - repre¬sentatives of the banks holding the notorious bills signed by the late' M. Gronier1—notably,' the “Ronvier” Bank, the Union Parisignne, the Austrian Laiderbank, and Messrs. Hindi have met and discussed the state of affairs with the directors of this Franco-Egyptian venture, in which, moreover, English capital is largely interested. No definite resolution has been adopted besides that to "urgently convence a general meeting of the shareholders, which will take place at Cairo.'The secretary of the company his already left for that place, to prepare'eventually measures for a- “conooidat" according to Egyptian company law, which, in any case, would be more pro¬fitable to the shareholders than a winding-up under French legislation. If certain statements are to be credited, the consolidation of the Sudrsries d' Egypte is indeed fraught with great and complicated difficulties. The Societe dee Raffiheries et Snoreriee d'Egypte is really an emalgamatioh of the various sugar concern formerly belong¬ing to the Daira Banish, and; according to its statutes, has to pay to the latter an annuity of 2,030,421 fra. The inability to pay, this amount would necessarily lead to a declaration of bankruptcy. It is in that direction, there¬fore, that the board will have to use all its endeavours. On the other hand, Hear from a' well-informed source; 17 out of the 18 banks which were reported to hold bills signed by M. -Grenier, and due- on September 1, had consented * to a moratorium, -and the' Banque Russo'Chinoise alone refused'to adhere to this arrange cut - Strong appeals -here made to the Russian Government to urge upon the director! of the Russo- Chimsed Bank to change their attitude. ‘ A point'iwhich also required etosidatioa has now been made clear. It was said at first that it was a request of the flay family to render accounts of the treat money- which drove1 M. Csenier to commit suicide. The real and direct cause, however, was that M. Oronier was unable to -settle a bill for 1,000,OOOfra, which matured on the fatal Saturday with the Anglo-Egypt Bank. • As we go to press we receive a telegram from our London correspondent informing M that Malta Carton de Wiart left London on Friday and will arrive at early-on Wednesday morning. Maltre Carton de Wiart’a advanced return to Egypt is connected with the Sucraries situation.

div.head: SEVERAL PERSONS STARRED.
div.p: Shortly Greek orchestra of tile Windsor. I seem to have shown rone intention till d’orchestre, who was when he drew a knife a the musician, stabbed him from the neck and shoulder. confusion followed. The wounded man, according to some, accounts, or one of his companonion accoriding to others, broke a violin over the assailant's head, .people hither and thither in a wild panic and the fact that the would-be murderer flourished his . knife,; and announced his intention in stabbing anyone who laid hands or him de¬terred those present from stopping him before he left the tent. Once outside the tent Agoao made off at remarkable speed the Cafe d’Afrique. Several individuals who tried to stop him were promptly stabbed, though their injuries were in no case severe. Once safely past the cafe the culprit turned into’ the aide alleys, where there are no police; and twisting and dodging at fall, speed disap¬peared from view. ’ The mamour of the Attarin hfaB. i to the spot end had already opened an en¬quiry when Cobbe Bey, the ' dant of Police was communicicated with. An agent was sent to San Stefano, another watched Agoeo'a house in Mehaneas Bay, and others search for the criminal thoughout the town. Meanwhile something like a panic prevailed many of those who had witnessed the outrage and Bemhefhl Cobbe while driving to the Attarin carocol was approached by several agitated. whose fears were calmed by him hat every measure had been to arrest the criminal. At 9.80p.m. j to his house and found a secret waiting for him. He drew a revolver and attempted to blow out his brains. The atanioide failed and Agoan was carried to the Government hospital. On arrival, he was found to be intoxicatded and to have a bullet embedded in his skill which was immediately ekUteted He is now doing well The wounded musician, Pietro Dattftowfu, and the other four persons injured will in no case require more6than seven days faettMrt. It appears . that Mr. Danflohiti had suddenly made a complaint to the British OoMdett against Agoeo who had threatened him on several occasions. The criminal is a British subject and will appeal before the-Consalar Court as soon as he has recovered from his self-inflicted injuries. With a view - to preventing the of similar crimes and the temporary of their perpetrators in the dusk 1 fall, the acting Commandant of Porch Police orders that ghaffin shall parade in 1 7 pm. instead of 8 p.m. in* the I et" 6 pm. instead of 7 p.m. in the winter months. The decision seems to eminently sound one, end we acting Commandant and the I the expedition with' which they arrested a most dangerous and irrespnosible aooahdrtl, The S.S. Tebe leaves Genoa today with sixty Italian delegates on board, who will attend the Colonial conference which is to be held at Asmara, the mountain station which is the sanatorium for the colony of Eritrea The Tebe arrives here next Sunday and .will start for the Canal and Massowah next day. On their return from the congress the delegates will land at' Suez and pass ten -days or so at Cairo.

div.head: September 11, 1905
A PROPOS DES “SUCRERTES”
div.p: On a dit de Cronier qu’il etait I’adminiatra teur ideal des Sacreries dont lexistence ne pouvait etre assuree que par l’appoint de ses speculations tonjoars heureuses. Par consequent,’ plus de Cronier, plus d cannes sacra, plus da Sucreries ni da Raffi nerie possibles an Egypte. Un journal du Caire, apres avoir admia que la Societe pouvait aisement ameliorer sa situa- tion, si lea 20 millions de la Sugar Corporation dtaient saufs, n’en assurait pas moins quelqnes jours apres, alors que oette somme etait officien semant declaree intacte, que lea Sncrerio, e tai ant irreme liablement von ees a la faillitc. Sir Ernest Cassel, la Daira Sanieh et la National Bank pouvaient bien en prolonger lea jours, mais non les suaver. Lea raisons que faisait valoir le journal en question dtaieat lea suivantes : 1. la Societe tra vaille aperte, et 2. le travail sera bientot arrete parlemanque de la matiere prem ere indispensa¬ble : la canne. Ainsi plus on fabriquera de sacs de sucre, plus on perdra de l’argent.Cela me rap pelle oe que disait an lendemain do Kracli Philippart un journal de cette villa a propos des trama d’Alexandrie : “Plus ile transportent de voyageura, plus ila perdent de l'argent.” Et il etait pas seul defendre ce paradoxe ; an autre journal, qui a empruntd son nom an marohd des titres, prouvait en meme tempa par une ingenieuse combination de chiffres que lactif des Trama etait presque nul, que l’ex- ploitation en dtait ruineuse et qu’il fallait se debarrasser des actions dividendes tout an moins (elles dtaient alora a 21 fr.) car, soutenait, elles ne calent pas un sou ! Le conseil ne fut quere saivi suivi oil en alex andrins qui se respectent on MSo off re point qu’en matidre financiere la lumidre vienne du Caire. L'on ne s'en trouva pas pins mal pour cela,paisqu’il y a bean tamps que lea titres sont a fra. 350 et plus. Bref, je ne puis partager lea vues qae le journal de la capitale a emises tant sur la va- lenr dea titres de la Societe des Sucreries en cas de non liquidation, que aur I'aveuir de l’in- duatrie auoridre en Egypte. La preuve, par dea donndas precises, que la culture de la canne eat moins lucrative que celle des cereales et meme du coton dans la Haute-Egypte, reate encore a faire. Lea ter¬rains, d’ailleura, ne font paa defaut. En effet, lea centaines de mille de fed dana gagnes et k gagner a l’irrigation perenne soot an tant de terrains nouveaux devenua propres a la culture de la canoe qui compenseront non seulement lea deficits de recolte mais pourront aveo uue gestion bien oom prise augmentar dans de fortes proportions la faculte de production des sucreries egyp tiennes. Pour cela le developpement du reseau des ohemina de fer ex-Data eat necessaire sure dans le bassin de l’lbtahimieh ; une meil- leure direction et des reformes sent egalement indispensables dans l “Ibrahimieh Ploughing Cy" la Societe des Sucreries, tout en venant en aide a la classe agricole, pent encore se order une source de revenus important^ an organistant sur ses voies un service de voyageura et de marchandises, eu installant des uaiues d’dgro- e dans lea immenses usines de la Daira, qui serviront ausai de depots pour lea odrdales, le coton, eta. Elle peat, en un mot, se rendre in¬dispensable tant aux proprietaires qa’aux fel¬lahs de la Haute Egypte qui beneficieroint de certaines reductions, s’ils ont aveo la Societe un contrat de rat de canne tons lea 2 ans. Le systeme, par tout oh il a dtd employe, a donnd des resultata ineaperes, meme en Egypte ou il a ete applique, tres maladroitement d’ailleura. Le prix de la canne sera certainement tou- jours plus eleve ici qu’k Cuba on a Java, mais une exploitation bien comprise pent depuis 1’abolition des primes laisser en Egypte nr e large marge de benfices, surtout ai lon par- vient a se passer completement do charbon par one meilleura utilisation de la bagaeee comme combustible. Il eat vrai que les snores dgyptieua out a latter sar leur propre marchr aveo lea sucres russes, grace a la prime, sont d’un prix de revient tres bas ; mais il y a un moyen de mettre le detaillant a meme d’ ache ter du sucre dgyptien qni eat de qualite superieure an meme prix que le sucre rasse ; c'est d’doartor les nombreaux intermd- diaires qui ae placent entre la societe et le detaillant eu chargeant moyannant une legere commisaion la “Salt and Soda” de la vente en son lieu et place du sucre dgyptieu dans les 120 chounahs et sux 20,000 detaillants diB- sdmiuda dans tout le pays. Eile realisersit ainsi une economie considerable de depots, personnel, etc. L'affaire ainsi envisagde ne pent dtre que productive. Maia, pour atteindre ce but, et ici j’ai le plaiair detre en parfait accord avec lo journal cairote, an ohangement de direction, une reorganisation complete des services et at regime severe d'economies tant aur le cout de la fabrication que aur lea fraia generaux, B’inc- posent absolument. Pour la realisation de telles reform ea le reinforcement du Conseil d’Administration est ndaessaire. Le ohoix devrait BO porter sur Sir Elwin Palmer et M. Deboarg, deux personnalities remArquables, k qui est du d’aiHears le relevement de la Salt and Soda Cy, qui etait k deux doigts de ft perte. Aux vides qui pourraient ae produire an sein du Cooieil on pourrait supplier par la nomination d'adminiatratears residant dans le paye, l'biver comme l' ete. MM. M. Salvage, G.Zervudachi, S.K. Harari pacha, F.Bonrgeoic’ directeur de la Cie da Gar k Alexandria, nous SEMBLUNT reuinir lu qualities necessaries pourdevenir des faoteure importanta pour le releve de la Sooidtk. Societe sages mesures one fois prises je n’hdri- tarai pas an iutaot k aphter des soliores Sucreries, mime a ft- 100, quel que sort Us suprises que nous reserve le bilan, A. Spink.

div.head: Notre Correspondant a New-York
div.p: Hier aprks-midi a e'e odlkbrd le manage do notre correspondant a New-York, M. G. E, Dibo avec Mile Nabiha Nauphal. La ceremonie ainsi qae la fete qni a suivi ont ea lien dans la plus stricte intimite. Seals les parents des non veaux marids y asBiataient. div.head: EXCAATIONS IN UPPER EGYPT.
COTTON FROM BRITISH EAST AFRICA.
div.p: Professor Garstang writes to the "Times" as follows: -The expedition which left here at Christmas time last year to make excavations between Edfu and Esna in Upper Egypt has returned, and the objects of antiquity discovered have arrived in England, after a somewhat prolonged season. Hierakonpolis, the home of Egypt’s earliest kings, was the place selected for first investiga¬tion. The palace site is well known from the researches of former explorers, and conse¬quently the present excavations were made rathet in the outlying township, which proved to be almost wholly of proto-dynastic age. Immediately below the rubbish of more recent times, strata representing the third and earlier dynasties were comes upon ; it was even pos Bible in some instances to trace the walls of houses and the disposition of rooms and passages of that remote date, about 3000 B.C. Vases of alabaster and granite, as well as Hint knives of conspicuously delicate workmanship, and other small objects, served to illustrate the archaeology of the time and locality, As the dry season came on, however, the ground in general proved too hard for the careful excavation demanded by so important a site, and work thereon was postponed until a more favourable season. Meanwhile within the great fortress which stands immediately opposite upon the edge of the western desert and seems to have been built in a contemporary age for the protection of this palace, it was found by experiment that previous excavators had not penetrated deeply enough to reach its lowest historical strata. At a depth which varied according to the accu¬mulation of sand from two to three metres be¬low the existing surface, a whole necropolis of the prehistoric are was discovered and excavat¬ed : 1»8 graves were registered and photo¬graphed in detail, Ihey seem to range in date from about the middle portion of the pre dynastic sequence until the beginning of the first dynasty. in themselves they have provided much that is of interest, and in relation to the walls of the fortress, associated with the tomb structures of later date upon the outside, have furnished reliable evidence that the fortress itself belongs to a date lying between the first and third dynasties. At the completion of that excavation, after nearly two months of works, explorations were made throughout the whole region lying south¬ward as far as Histayeh. Tentative excavations were made at several points. At Edfu the remains seem to be of Ptolemaic times, while at Hiasayeh some interesting funereal furniture and hieroglyphic papyri of pro-Ptolemaio date were discovered in the debris of a former exca vation. Plundering during very reoent times had rendered these sites unsuitable for the continuous work of an organised expedition ; consequently, after the third month, camp was fixed at Esna on the northern limit of the concession. As is often the case, rumours that the place had been plundered had in some measure saved it for the excavators. The smaller tombs of the great necropolis at once gave evidenoe of their origin during the Hyksoa period ; it seems probable (though the results of further excavation must be awaited before a definite conclusion can be established) that the site came into being daring the pressure from the north in those troubled times upon the oapi’al at Thebes. During the prosperous era of the Egyptian monarchy which followed—the age of the Pharaohs of the eighteenth and nine¬teenth dynasties—the site at Esna seems to have fallen into neglect ; but from the twent¬ieth dynasty, which heralded the period of the decline of the Egyptian power power, about 100 B.C., Esna again came into prominenoe. Two great mounds, conspicuous in the desert from afar, proved to be tomb structures of this later date. These, cleared of their accumulated sand, disclosed great structures of brick in good preservation, which comprises a series of eight or ten chambers upon the ground-floor with a stairway leading up to a similar series above. The arches and vaults were pointed, in nearly every case. In a stone-lined chamber within the largest structure there was found the head of an apis carved in stone, of the time of Raineses VI., and numerous remains of animals sacrificed at that shrine were found within the chamber. These structures were in reality great tombs, built, it would seem, for the permanent use of some fomily. Unfort¬unately, a conflagration within the chambers, which seemed to have been deliberately brought about, had destroyed much arcbasologioal evidence ;but the architecture illustrated is of a new interst. The largest of those tombs stood upon abase 14 8 metres (nearly 50ft.) square ; and its height was half its length, measured from its lowest course, deep in the sand, to the existing summit, which seems to be original. The annual exhibition of antiquities discover- cd (which in previous years under the same auspices has been held in Burlington Hone.) will be held this year, owing to the lateness of the season, in the premises of the Institute of Archmology of this Univvreity ; it will be open for inspection towards the end of the present month. The "Bulletin of the Imperial Institute” writes as follows :— Samples of five varieties of cotton, including ginned and unginned specimens of each, were recently forwarded to the Imperial Institute by the Director of Agriculture for the East Africa Protectorate, together with a memoran¬dum on their cultivation. These samples have been submitted to avami nation in the scientific and technical department of the Imperial Institute, and have been referred to commercial experts for valua¬tion. An account of the results of the investi¬gation is given below. The following interesting particulars relat¬ing to the sample labelled "No. J. 6, Lamu Cotton” were supplied by the Director of Agriculture in the memorandum referred to above. The plant which yields this cotton is a variety of Goseyptum kerbaceum, which was probably introduced into East Africa from India at an early date, and has long been grown on the Bajoon coast. The quantity of cotton fibre produced in this district amounts , to about six tons per annnm, part of which is . used locally for stuffing pillows, and part is exported to India. The cotton is plant- i ed in April, and the crop is gathered from October to January. The seed is sown on sandy soil, in holes about three i feet apart, in some cereal crop or in sesame^ ;. after the latter crop has been harvested the 1 cotton is left on the land, but receive’ no , farther cultivation. Cotton is collected from ! the same plants for at least five years, but owing to growth of weeds and bush, the plants gradually become fewer in number, and finally disappear. The average yield of cotton is probably less than 100 pounds per acre. The large amount of leaf and boll fragments in the cotton is due to the method of colleo- tion. The whole capsules are gathered, and the cotton, after being roughly removed, is beaten on a mattress, when the greater part1 of the dry leaves and capsules are powdered j and fall to the ground. The cotton is then ‘ ginned by means of a pair of small wooden j rollers. The ootton is sold at about 2 jd. per pound. The samples consisted of 2 pounds of ginned ' cotton and I pound of the unginned product. Both specimens, especially the unginned con¬tained a large amount of fragments of leaves and bolls. The seeds were very small and closely invested with short, white downy hairs, The cotton was white with numerous buff-coloured stains ; it was harsh, of fair strength, and 0'6 to 0 9 incheas long. The fibre would not be of much value for i spinning alone, but could be used for mixing 1 with cotton of a higher grade. The commercial experts reported that the 1 ginned ootton was of too low a quality to class, ! but was perhaps worth Id. per pound. It is stated in the memorandom furnished ' by the Director of Agriculture that the sample ’ labelled "No. J. 7, Fort Hall Cotton,” is pro-1 bably derived from an American variety. The i cotton was grown experimentally by H.M. ; sub commissioner on damp, shallow, dark loam, i was planted in December 1903, and harvested ' in June 1904. The sample consisted of about one pound of ginned and one pound of unginned cotton. I The seeds were dark brown in colour and bore 1 a small white tuft at the pointed end; in i some cases they were covered with a light ' brown or brownish green down. The cotton was of bright appearance, was cream-coloured, fairly soft, of rather poor strength, and from 1*0 to 1*5 inches long. | The commercial experts reported that the cotton, was, on the whole, of good silky staple, but somewhat mixed and worth d. per pound, "middling American” cotton being quoted at 4^ d. per pound on the same date. The sample labelled “No. J. 8, Kibwezi Cotton, Afifi” was stated to have been grown from Egyptian seed by an Arab at Kibwezi, by means of irrigation on shallow rocky soil. The cotton was planted in March and har¬vested in September. The plants were healthy and produced a large number of capsnles. The samples consisted of 3 pounds of ginned cotton, and 1| pounds of the unginned mater¬ial. The ungiuned cotton was fairly clean but was to a large extent unripe. The seeds corresponded to those of Egyptian "mitafifi,” but a considerable portion terminated in a sharp point and resembled the seed of the so-called "hindi” cotton, the old white cotton of Egypt, which commonly occurs associated with “mitafifi” and lowers the value of that product. In Egypt it is the custom on select¬ing the seeds for sowing to reject all these sharp-pointed seeds. The sample was of uneven colour with occa¬sional brown stains; the fibre was of very irregular strength, fairly soft to the touch, and 1 0 to 13 inches long. The commercial experts reported that the cotton was deeply stained, but of fair staple and worth about 3d. per pound, ‘ fully good fair brown Egyptian” cotton being quoted at 6 l/8d. per pound on the same date. The sample labelled "No. J. 9, M’hindi Cotton, Malindi.” Cotton is said to be a variety of Gouypium peruvtanum. The plants occur singly on the coast, and also grow at Voi and Teavo. The tree is growing as a perennial, and very little ootton of this variety is prodnoed. The sample consisted of 1 pound 8 ounces of unginned cotton and 1 pound of ginned cotton. The cotton was of the "kidney” variety, the black seeds being united in groups Of about seven. The cotton was easily detached from the seeds and was of uneven colour, being cream-coloured with occasional reddish-brown stains. The fibre was fairly soft, of poor strength, and 0*9 to It faohai long.

div.head: BECK and CD’S PILSENER BEER
div.p: BUEMEN. years to HONEST COMPETITION FOR QOALITT. H.B- Inferiro brands now being offered to max of certain food releases* Beware of fully competition. The commarcial experts reported that the sample was of very good staple, hut con¬tained a good deal of “dead” cotton cotton which is immature and unable to re¬tain dyes), and was worth about 4 jtf. per pound, “middling American” cotton being valued at 4 }d. per pound on the same date. The sample labelled "No. J. 10, Kiaumu Cotton” consisted of 1 j pounds of unginned and 2 pounds of ginned cotton. The cotton appeared to consist of two distinct varieties, the fibre of one being white whilst that of the other was reddish. The reddish ootton had dark brown seeds bearing a small, green¬ish tuft, whilst the white cotton had black, sharply-pointed seeds like those of "hindi” cotton. The ginned cotton was of a pale reddish oolour with occasional brown stains. The fibre was soft to the touch, of irregular strength, and 10 to 13 inohea long. The commercial exports reported that the cotton was of very hard staple, and was worth about 5 d. per pound, "fully good fair brown Egyptian” cotton being quoted at 6 id. per pound on the same date. In conclusion, the results of this investiga¬tion prove that these cottons are, on the whole, of promising quality, but that they show evidence of lack of care in cultivation. If more care were employed, particularly in the selection of seed for sowing end in the harvesting of the cotton, there can be no doubt that a product could be obtained which would be readily rateable in the English market. THE ENGINE OB THE FUTURE. The gas-eugine is regarded as the prime mover of the future, and because of this, importance is attached to a dear statement, by a writer in “Engineering,” of the principal difficulties which remain to be overcome in order to enable large engines operating with poor gas in general to work with safety, facility of control and upkeep — attributes which appear to have remained the special feature of the s team -engine. Economically the gas- engine is evidently superior, but low consump¬tion is not the only quality which users require from a motive power. It is necessary above all that it should be free from the risk of sudden stoppages, which lead to great expense, as they hamper production, and may be at times fatal in certain industries where break¬downs must be especially avoided ; such is the case with electric stations, pumping, hoisting and ventilating work in mines, Ac. The principal causes of breakdowns in engines fed by gas other than town gas, which undergoes a complete purification, consists in the foaling of parts, such as the pipes, the valves, and the oylinder, by impurities in the gas. In large installations, where it is extremely important to avoid breakdowns, resourse is had to special means of washing and purifying, by the use of centrifugals and other apparatus. But although these succeed in reducing to 1/5 gramme per cubiometretheamountofdustaccompanying the gas, they still allow the passage of tar, which is the principal element destructive to the engine. This tar adheres to the sides of the passages, causes the valves and piston-rings to attack,thua preventing their proper action. It also deposits itself in the cylinder, where it finally gives rise to premature ignitions.Certain coke-oven gases contain as much as 1 gramme of tar per cubic metre. It is this very question of tar which compels us, in order to avoid great complica¬tions, to employ exclusively non-caking anthra¬cite coal for annotion gas-producers, now so largely in nee owing to their simplicity and economical efficiency. As tar is a product of the volatile carbons (carbides) which escape combustion and on the conversion into fuel- gas, it is to our intersts to reduce them in the producer itself. Different systems have been proposed, amongst which is the system of in¬verted combustion, which is said to have the result of burning the volatile matters as they are given off, and the distillation of the hydro¬carbons in the independent reducers. It must be admitted that BO far the efforts of the inventors have not met with the success expected. The caking of the fuel and the for¬mation of cavities injurious to the regularity of combustion constitute the principal difficulty to combat. The use of bituminous coal, espe¬cially in suction gas producers, is not,therefore, a question which has been industrially accom¬plished. Whether it is producer-gas, blast¬furnace gas, or coke-oven gas which is used, their purity is an important factor in the propet working of the engines whioh they feed. The organic defects of large engines do not appear to play in this respect a preponderating part. They should, however, be perfected as regards facility of access and upkeep of the parts, such as valves and piston. The oil con¬sumption should be low, and they should be made less susceptible to variations in the quality of the gas. The skill of our experts and our makers will, we have no doubt, Boon overcime these latter difficulties, large gas- engines will then constitute one of the most remarkable industrial victories of the age in whioh we live.

div.head: IN AND OUT OF FLEET-STREET.
div.p: "What do they know of England who only England know 1" What do they even know of London 1 How, many of her children realise her splendour, her mystery, and her beauty 1— for beautiful she is, with a beauty of her own: She is worn and weary with her age-long matron hood ; she is ill-dressed, untidy, a care¬less, tired queen ; but a queen all the same, with royal footsteps and moments when she flashes on yon a strange charm more pene¬trating than that of her younger sisters decked in rose and gold. But her sons and daughters know her not. They go about their toil or pleasure with unseeing eyes. To them London is a place to make money in, or to spend it, the site of the workshop, the office, the club, the restaurant, but otherwise just a spoilt fragment of earth’s surface, serrated with mean streets and grey buildings. So when we want beauty we hasten away from London to seek aesthetic impressions elsewhere, ignoring those that lie so dose at hand. Most of us in these days, though we may be no great travellers, have made acquaintance with many famous cities, with some of the earth's show places. We have rooked in a gondola on a summer night in venice, and heard the boatman's deep “stall” as we glided from the blaok shadows into the squares of silver. We have stood at midday on the shore of the Bay of Naples and looked back from a sea of white and purple to the cone of Vesuvius shimmer- ing in an orange base of light We have seen the Pacific plashing in long rollers at the Golden Gate, and the Atlantic licking the palms and pines of the low Florida shore : we have counted the minarets of Stamboul and the gilded domes and painted roofs of Mosoow. Yet, in her own way, London can be as im¬pressive as any of these. To tens and hundreds of thousands of those who navigate this roaring strait of traffic, Fleet-street I suppose, is no more than a huddle of shops, taverns, and newspaper offces, too crowded to be comfortable. Yet Fleet- street can give us one of the finest sights in the world. Come down it on the top of a 'bus, and forget for a moment your evening paper and the Test match. Slowly the heavy vehicle threads its way down the crooked, sloping street. The curve (how many Londoners could tell you that Fleet-street is not straight?) shuts off the view, till you are well past Fetter-lane. Then of a sudden it opens out be¬fore you a stirring prospect. At your feet the Bridge-street creasing seethes and boils, men and horses struggling, as it seems, in a black whirlpool. The railway bridge, holds a train of carriages, a panting engine, suspended above their heads. Beyond it, Ludgate-hiU, thrust¬ing its irregular zigzag of facades upon yon, rising steeply like a stairway, to where the Cathedral closes in the prospect Ponderous, majestic, impenetrable, massive, the great Christian church sits on the world-old hill where once the Romans made their offerings in the Temple of Diana. The mighty dome hangs aloft in air, shutting out a vast segment of grey sky and flying eoud, filling np the horizon*: portentous in its size, by contrast with every¬thing else, swelling, in free and noble curves, like a mother's breast leaning, benign and gracious over the little dark oity, the tense and hurrying crowds below. For several years of my life it was my lot to drive from Fleet-street to Chelsea between midnight and early morning. An unromantic journey, surely , yet I seldom made it without wondering afresh at the strange and fanciful aspects of some of our London streets in the time of slumber. F.eet-street itself has no snob time of rest It is the one thoroughfare in London that never sleeps. There is no hour in the twenty-four when you will not find Fleet-street broad awake, with lights winking from its casements, and men and horses datter- on its wood and flagstones. As your h*n- som spins aloDg, it passes groups of waiting carts, men shooting bags and bundles into vans yawning open at the kerb, messengers diving briskly into and out of the offioee. Up the middle of the street, oarelen of the rackety newspaper carts aad the impatient hansoms, there swings slowly a great wagon, bound for Covent Garden Market. It is piled high with green stuff or fragrant ba keta of fruit , two horses, harnessed in single file, draw it with sturdy, earth-shaking stride ; the driver, with high whip quivering in an ample loop over his shoulder, slouches heavily beside his cattle, or nods upon them from the shafts. It brings a breath of the Kentish hedgerows and com- fields as it ploughs its steady purposeful way up the worrying little street. Like a battleship, amid its covey of fi lgeting destroyers, the big wagon forges on, till it creaks ponderously round the corner by Wellington-street, and strains up the bill towards the market. That particular fragment of London is always full of contrasts. In the win ter and early spring, on Friday night, I used to touch one that I always thought peooliarly poignant As you passed by the Law Courts and beyond the two churohes into the Strand, you would see a long line of men. The vehicles were the hansoms waiting to take people away from the Covent Garden fancy dress ball : the men were the hungTy wretches tramping wearily towards General Booth’s kitchen, where a bowl of warm soup was to be had. At the point of Aldwych and the Kings way, where two columns cross, you might see, on there nights,* canons scene. Some of General Booth’s clients looked evil as well as hungry, but had nothing to fear ; there is a capable sergeant of police,and two or three big, vigilant constables. One of them holds up his hand with the immortal gesture that is the symbol of civic law and order, end a pushing hansom stops, with instant obedience, to allow a country eart to get past The beam from a high standard lamp is thrown right upon the two people, male and female sitting in the back Tha man is middleaged with a and oiled moustache. He we are evening dress, and he is smoking a plump cigar, whose savour floats gratefully to the nestriis. The woman is young, and rather handsome ; there is a star of diamonds in her fair hair, and the clock which falls open at the front reveals a pendant of Dearls and turqnises on the white throat. Man and woman are talking a little too gaily, there is a slight vinous flush on both faces, and the perfume of heliotrope and violets mingles with the fine fragrant of the tobacco. Not exactly an idyl ; still, you may see worse pictures. And so, perhaps, think the two or three outliers from the other pro¬cession, the walking one, who share the spectacle with me. They stand heavily, like men whose boots are broken and their feet sore; their clothes are horrible ; their hair is matted and tousled under battered old hats ; their faces are not nice to look upon. With strange questioning eyes they stare at the couple in the hansom, at the lady, so white and smooth and scented, at the sleek gentleman, overcoming the fumes of a guinea bottle of champagne with an eighteen penny. Well, it is the eternal antithesis, not limited to the Strand on a Friday night in spring. On the one side, youth and luxury, and the jots cfe vivre ; on the other, men who have walked four miles to get a crust and a mug of broth. And between the two, with vigilant eyes on both, the tall constables and the majesty of the Established Order. But we had better stop here, for we are getting away from Fleet-street.

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
